bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to E.S. Adams, January 29, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Adams for the copy of a map of Camp Columbia. He requests additional maps of sites used by the U.S. Army Yellow Fever Board, in 1900-1901.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to E.S. Adams, January 29, 1941
div1.opener:
January 29, 1941
Major General E. S. Adams
The Adjutant General
War Department
Washington, D. C.
AG 095-Hench, Philip S., Dr.
(9-18-40)M
My dear General Adams:
div1.p:
In response to my request of September 13, 1940, which was answered
by you, on September 26, 1940, I received some weeks ago a copy of a map of Camp
Columbia, Cuba: survey under the direction of Major M. M. Patrick, Corps of
Engineers by a detachment of the Second Battalion Engineers, June, 1907. In the
right lower corner of this map, the following penciled identification is written:
Military Information Division, map section--Columbia Camp, G 30-07-2, Mil. Sta.,
Cuba. I appreciate the receipt of this map very greatly.

General Albert E. Truby, retired, now living in San Francisco,
was commanding officer of the Post Hospital at Camp Columbia in 1900-1901. He and
I are trying to identify for the Minister of National Defense of the Cuban govern-
ment the sites used by the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Board (Walter Reed and colleagues)
in 1900. We have been unable to find any maps of the camp as of 1900 or 1901.
Do you have any available? I will be most grateful to receive two copies. Also
would it be possible for me to obtain a key of identification to the numbered
buildings in the 1907 map which you already sent me? I should like to have the
identification of all the buildings, but especially of those in the lower right
band quadrant of the map which made up the Post Hospital. I have studied the
map carefully with a magnifying glass and have been unable to find any buildings
numbered 88, 94, 95, 96, 97, 100 and 105, nor are the following buildings marked:
that behind 91 and 92, that northwest of 99, that beside 111, those near 102 and
103 and the ones adjacent to 108. Walter Reed and his colleagues lived at this
Post Hospital and did much of their work there, before setting up Camp Lazear.
I would be most grateful for whatever help you can give me and if you could send
me another copy of the 1907 map I should like to make comments thereon and send it
to General Truby. Whatever charge is necessary, I shall be glad to pay.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
